EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Mennel Milling Company of Michigan operates a large mill in

Dowagiac, Michigan, that processes wheat into many different

grades of flour.  Several of the grades involve a process in

which chlorine is added to the milled flour to achieve a desired

pH.  In addition, a small amount of chlorine is added to the

wheat prior to storage and milling to inhibit microbial growth.



Chlorine is delivered to Mennel Milling Co. and used in one ton

containers and 150-pound containers.  The supplier delivers full

chlorine containers to the site via truck.  The containers are

unloaded and stored in the indoor storage area by the use of an

overhead crane rail hoist.  Mennel Milling staff connects the ton

containers and 150-pound cylinders to the feed system.  The

maximum number of ton containers is 6 (12,000 pounds) and 150-

pound cylinders is 3 (450 pounds).



Mennel Milling Co. uses vacuum feed systems that are inherently

safe.  These systems involve the use of air or water flowing

through an eductor that creates a vacuum.  This vacuum allows for

the feed of chlorine from the containers into the piping system.

If a chlorine line downstream of the vacuum regulator is broken

or develops a leak, the vacuum is interrupted and the vacuum

regulator automatically closes, preventing the discharge of

chlorine gas.



Mennel Milling Co. has contracted with Research Products Co.

(REPCO) of Salina, Kansas to perform preventive and corrective

maintenance on the chlorine feed systems.



Mennel Milling Co. has developed a comprehensive, accidental

release prevention program as part of the OSHA PSM program.  The

elements of this program include:

     u    Process Safety Information

u    Process Hazard Analysis

u    Operating Procedures

u    Training

u    Management of Change

u    Pre-Startup Safety Review

u    Compliance Audits

u    Incident Investigation

u    Contractor Management

     u    Hot Work Permits



I

n the past five years, there have been no accidental releases of

chlorine at Mennel Milling Co. that have resulted in deaths,

injuries, or significant damage on site, or known offsite deaths,

injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or

environmental damage.



An Emergency Action Plan has been developed for the site.  This

plan contains measures that Mennel Milling Co. staff can take to

alert employees to a release, how to distinguish between an

incidental release and a significant release, and many other

elements.  Mennel Milling Co. staff will receive training to

allow for defensive action in response to an on-site release.  In

the event of a chlorine release, Mennel Milling will contact the

Dowagiac Fire Department for technical support.  The fire

department is trained and equipped to respond to chlorine

incidents.  The facility has coordinated its emergency response

activities with the City of Dowagiac Fire Department and the Cass

County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



Mennel Milling Co. has reviewed hazard evaluations previously

prepared for the chlorination processes at the facility.  As a

result of this evaluation, several changes are planned to improve

safety.  These changes include (but are not limited to):



     u    When meetings of the Chlorine Safety Team are convened,

       minutes should be taken and retained on file.

u    Develop a system to ensure that the findings and

recommendations of the revalidated PHA are addressed.

u    Provide for an annual review of the written operating

procedures and certify that they are current and accurate.

u    Provide annual operations and maintenance training

including:

          o    Confirm that all affected employees have received the

            necessary training and that the tests used to determine their

            competency are on file.

o    Implement the training program included in Section 5.0 of

the PSM Program.  It is recommended that th

e outline contained in

that section and in Appendix D be used for this training.

o    Ensure that the operating procedures, operating limits,

safety and health considerations, and safety systems are included

in the training.

          o    Document that the employees have received and understood the

            training by administering a test.

     u    Implement the contractor management program as described in

       the PSM program including the following.

          o    Contact Research Products (and other contractors working on

            or around the chlorine system) and request that they complete the

            Contractor's Safety Questionnaire, Contractor Safety

            Certification Form, and the Contractor Employee Safety Affidavit.

o    Provide contractors (including Research Products) a copy of

Section 2.0 (Process Safety Information) and Section 9.0 (Hot

Work Permit) of the PSM Program.

o    Provide contractors (including Research Products) a copy of

the Emergency Action Plan for the facility.

     u    ERM will modify the Mechanical Integrity element of the PSM

       Program to indicate that Research Products visits the site to

       perform service inspections approximately every other month.

u    Review the Emergency Action Plan for the facility including

the following:

          o    Ensure that the plan includes all of the required elements

            of OSHA and the EPA.

o    Develop a written procedure for investigating chlorine

alarms.

o    Attempts to schedule periodic drills with the Fire

department to test the Emergency Action Plan.

     u    Review all recommendations from the past and most current

       audit, assign responsibility, track and document responses until

       completion.

u    Modify Section 6.0 of the RMP to include a matrix defining

the responsibilities of various Mennel staff for the various

prevention program elements.

u    Develop a system that will ensure that a compliance a

udit of

the PSM Program is performed every three (3) years.

u    Resubmit the updated RMP after the USEPA has finalized and

published the revised submission requirements.  This submission

is due in June 2004, five years after the initial submission was

made.
